conclusion: The cube has a side length a and a refractive index n = 1.5. A bubble is located at the center of the cube. We need to determine the minimum area of paper required such that the bubble is not visible from any external direction.
For the bubble to be invisible from an external direction, the light ray entering the cube should either reflect off the surface or refract out of the paper.
The critical angle for total internal reflection (TIR) occurs when the angle of incidence is equal to the critical angle θc, given by sin(θc) = 1/n = 2/3.
The maximum angle from which the bubble can still be seen is determined by the critical angle. This angle subtends an arc of a/2 from the center of the cube.
The radius r is the distance from the center of the cube to the edge of one face, i.e., r = a/√2.
The critical angle θc forms a sector of a circle with radius r = a/√2.
The area of this sector is given by πr²(θc/2π) = π(a/√2)²(θc/2) = (πa²arcsin(2/3))/4.
